title: 2D and 3D Shapes
description: Learn about flat (2D) and solid (3D) shapes and their features
objectives: Tell the difference between 2D (flat) and 3D (solid) shapes
Name common 3D shapes: cube, sphere, cylinder, cone
Describe features of shapes using sides, corners, faces, and edges

sections.title: Flat Shapes and Solid Shapes!
sections.content:
In Foundation, you learned about flat shapes like circles, squares, and triangles. These are called **2D shapes** (two-dimensional) because they are flat.

But what about a ball, a box, or a can? These are **3D shapes** (three-dimensional) because they are solid -- you can pick them up and hold them!

Today we will learn about both 2D and 3D shapes and how to describe them.

sections.title: 2D Shapes: Sides and Corners
sections.content:
**2D shapes** are flat. You can draw them on paper.

| Shape | Sides | Corners |
|-------|-------|---------|
| Circle | 0 (curved) | 0 |
| Triangle | 3 | 3 |
| Square | 4 (all equal) | 4 |
| Rectangle | 4 (two pairs) | 4 |
| Pentagon | 5 | 5 |
| Hexagon | 6 | 6 |

A **side** is a straight edge. A **corner** (or **vertex**) is where two sides meet.

sections.title: 3D Shapes: Faces, Edges, and Corners
sections.content:
**3D shapes** are solid. You can hold them in your hand.

**Sphere** -- shaped like a ball
- 0 flat faces, 0 edges, 0 corners
- It is curved all over

**Cube** -- shaped like a dice or a box with equal sides
- 6 flat faces (all squares), 12 edges, 8 corners

**Cylinder** -- shaped like a can
- 2 flat faces (circles) and 1 curved surface

**Cone** -- shaped like an ice-cream cone
- 1 flat face (circle) and 1 curved surface, 1 pointy tip

A **face** is a flat surface. An **edge** is where two faces meet. A **corner** (vertex) is a pointy bit.

sections.title: Example: Is It 2D or 3D?
sections.content:
Is a tin of baked beans a 2D or 3D shape?

1. Can you pick it up and hold it? **Yes.**
2. Does it take up space in all directions? **Yes.**
3. It is not flat -- it is solid.
4. So it is a **3D shape**.

What 3D shape is it? It has two flat circle faces and a curved surface in between. It is a **cylinder**!

sections.title: Example: Counting Faces on a Cube
sections.content:
How many faces does a cube have?

1. A cube is like a dice or a block.
2. Look at the top -- that is 1 face.
3. Look at the bottom -- that is 1 face.
4. Look at the front -- that is 1 face.
5. Look at the back -- that is 1 face.
6. Look at the left side -- that is 1 face.
7. Look at the right side -- that is 1 face.

1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = **6 faces**.

A cube has **6 faces**, and they are all squares!

sections.title: 2D vs 3D
sections.content:
**2D shapes** are flat. They have **sides** and **corners**.
- You can draw them on paper.
- Examples: circle, triangle, square, rectangle

**3D shapes** are solid. They have **faces**, **edges**, and **corners**.
- You can hold them in your hand.
- Examples: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone

3D shapes are made up of 2D shapes! For example, each face of a cube is a **square** (a 2D shape).

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Fantastic! In this lesson you learned:

- **2D shapes** are flat: circle, triangle, square, rectangle
- **3D shapes** are solid: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone
- 2D shapes have **sides** and **corners**
- 3D shapes have **faces**, **edges**, and **corners**
- 3D shapes are made up of 2D shapes

Look around your home -- can you find a sphere, a cube, a cylinder, and a cone?

workedExamples.title: Identifying a 3D Shape
workedExamples.problem: A shape looks like a ball. It has no flat faces and no corners. What 3D shape is it?
steps: It is shaped like a ball -- it is round.
It has no flat faces, no edges, and no corners.
A round 3D shape with no flat faces is a sphere.
workedExamples.explanation: A sphere is round like a ball. Unlike a cube, it has no flat faces, no edges, and no corners -- it is curved everywhere.

workedExamples.title: Finding 2D Shapes in 3D Shapes
workedExamples.problem: What 2D shape are the faces of a cube?
steps: Look at each face -- it has 4 equal sides and 4 corners.
A flat shape with 4 equal sides is a square.
So each face of a cube is a square.
workedExamples.solution: The faces of a cube are **squares**.
workedExamples.explanation: A cube is made up of 6 square faces. Each face is a flat square with 4 equal sides. This shows how 2D shapes make up 3D shapes!

title: Giving Directions and Making Turns
description: Give and follow directions using left, right, forward, and turns
objectives: Give and follow directions using left, right, and forward
Understand half turns and quarter turns
Describe movement and direction in everyday situations

sections.title: Which Way Do We Go?
sections.content:
Imagine you are a robot and someone needs to tell you exactly where to walk. They would say things like "go forward", "turn left", or "turn right".

Giving good **directions** helps people (and robots!) get where they need to go. Today we will learn about directions and turns!

sections.title: Left, Right, and Forward
sections.content:
There are three main directions to know:

- **Forward** -- straight ahead, the way you are facing
- **Left** -- the side where your left hand is
- **Right** -- the side where your right hand is
- **Backward** -- the opposite of forward, behind you

**How to remember left and right:**
Hold both hands up with your palms facing away from you. Spread your fingers and point your thumbs out. Your **left hand** makes an "L" shape!

When giving directions, tell someone:
1. Which way to face (turn left or turn right)
2. How far to go (2 steps forward)

sections.title: Half Turns and Quarter Turns
sections.content:
A **turn** is when you spin on the spot to face a new direction.

**Quarter turn** -- turn a small amount (like the corner of a square)
- You end up facing to your left or right
- It is called a quarter turn because you turn one quarter of the way around

**Half turn** -- turn halfway around
- You end up facing the **opposite direction**
- If you were facing the door, after a half turn you face the wall behind you

**Full turn** -- turn all the way around
- You end up facing the **same direction** you started

You can turn **clockwise** (the way clock hands move) or **anticlockwise** (the opposite way).

sections.title: Example: Following Directions
sections.content:
Follow these directions: Start at the door. Go forward 3 steps. Turn right. Go forward 2 steps.

1. Stand at the door, facing into the room.
2. Walk **forward 3 steps** (straight ahead).
3. **Turn right** (face to your right side).
4. Walk **forward 2 steps** in the new direction.

You have walked in an L-shape! Directions help you get exactly where you need to be.

sections.title: Example: Understanding Turns
sections.content:
Lily is facing the window. She makes a half turn. Which direction is she facing now?

1. Lily starts facing the **window**.
2. A half turn means she spins halfway around.
3. She now faces the **opposite direction**.
4. The opposite of the window is the **back wall**.

After a half turn, Lily faces the **back wall**.

sections.title: Types of Turns
sections.content:
Here is a summary of turns:

| Turn | How far | Where you end up |
|------|---------|------------------|
| Quarter turn | A small turn | Facing left or right |
| Half turn | Halfway around | Facing the opposite direction |
| Full turn | All the way around | Facing the same direction you started |

Remember: a quarter turn is like turning a corner, and a half turn is like doing an about-face!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Great work! In this lesson you learned:

- **Forward** means straight ahead, **left** and **right** are your two sides
- A **quarter turn** faces you to the left or right
- A **half turn** faces you the **opposite** direction
- A **full turn** brings you back to where you started
- Good directions use clear words like "go forward 3 steps, then turn left"

Try giving directions to a friend to help them find a hidden object!

workedExamples.title: Giving Directions
workedExamples.problem: How would you tell a friend to walk from the classroom door to the teacher's desk if the desk is to the left and 5 steps forward?
steps: Turn left to face the direction of the desk.
You arrive at the teacher's desk!
workedExamples.solution: The directions are: **Turn left. Go forward 5 steps.**
workedExamples.explanation: Good directions tell someone which way to turn and how far to go. Turning left first and then walking forward 5 steps gets you to the desk.

workedExamples.title: Working Out Turns
workedExamples.problem: Tom is facing north. He makes a quarter turn to the right. Which direction is he facing now?
steps: A quarter turn to the right means he turns a small amount clockwise.
North, then a quarter turn right, takes him to east.
workedExamples.explanation: If you face north and make a quarter turn to the right, you end up facing east. A quarter turn is like turning a corner -- you end up facing a direction that is sideways from where you started.
